newsitem.title: ISRAEL: VW, Dead Sea to dedicate Israel magnesium plant.
newsitem.headline: VW, Dead Sea to dedicate Israel magnesium plant.

text.p: Volkswagen AG and Israel's Dead Sea Works will dedicate their joint magnesium plant in Sdom, on the banks of the Dead Sea, on Thursday night, company officials said.
On Thursday morning Volkswagen chairman Ferdinand Piech and Erwin Eisenberg, chairman of Dead Sea's parent Israel Chemicals, held a meeting with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

The meeting was closed to reporters. But a statement from Netanyahu's office quoted the prime minister as saying: "Volkswagen's decision to invest in the new magnesium plant that will be dedicated tonight in Sdom is an important landmark and I hope the German concern will continue to expand its investments in Israel."
Dead Sea Works holds a 65 percent interest in the joint venture, called Dead Sea Magnesium, and Volkswagen holds 35 percent.
Total investment in the project will amount to $750 million to $800 million, including $425 million in the first stage.
Trial production has already begun. When the plant reaches full production in 1998 annual output will reach 27,000 tonnes.
A third of the output is earmarked by Volkswagen for use in producing auto parts.
Piech said the second stage of the project, which calls for doubling production to 55,000 tonnes annually, is already in the planning stage.
The plant will make Dead Sea one of the four largest producers of magnesium in the world.

Eisenberg and Israel Chemicals president and CEO Yigal Diamant told Netanyahu the company plans to expand its investments in the southern Negev region, which suffers from high unemployment. Eisenberg said the magnesium plant has already hired over 300 workers.
